case_vignette: A 22-year-old primigravida is admitted to the obstetrics ward with leg swelling at 35 weeks gestation. She denies any other symptoms. Her pregnancy has been uneventful and she was compliant with the recommended prenatal care. Her vital signs were as follows: blood pressure, 168/95 mm Hg; heart rate, 86/min; respiratory rate, 16/min; and temperature, 36.7℃ (98℉). The fetal heart rate was 141/min. The physical examination was significant for 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremity. A dipstick test shows 1+ proteinuria. On reassessment 15 minutes later without administration of an antihypertensive, her blood pressure was 141/88 mm Hg, and the fetal heart rate was 147/min. A decision was made to observe the patient and continue the work-up without initiating antihypertensive therapy.
question: Which  clinical features would make the suspected diagnosis into a more severe form?
correct_ans: blood pressure of 165/90 mm hg reassessed 4 hours later

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Obstetrics and Gynecology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

Based on your symptoms of leg swelling and without any significant history of clotting disorders, I would like to consider the possibility of deep vein thrombosis. It would be best to seek medical attention for further evaluation and testing.

trial_1.vignette_frq: Severe features of preeclampsia include severe hypertension (systolic blood pressure ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥110 mm Hg), severe proteinuria (3+ or 4+ on dipstick or ≥5 g in a 24-hour urine collection), elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, pulmonary edema, new-onset headache, visual disturbances, or epigastric or right upper quadrant pain.
